relation_surface: corrosion Under Thermal Insulation, and Fireproofing – A Systems Approach / Control of External Corrosion
rel_desc: Corrosion under thermal insulation is treated as a specific form of external corrosion in refinery and piping systems.
resolution_context: CUI is generally categorized as a specific manifestation of external corrosion on insulated external surfaces of equipment and piping.
justification: The chunk lists separate standards for 'Control of External Corrosion on Underground or Submerged Metallic Piping Systems' and for 'The Control of Corrosion Under Thermal Insulation, and Fireproofing', and the entities share the same external corrosion mechanism class grouping, implying CUI is a specialized case of external corrosion.
remark: Subtype relation inferred from domain context and shared classification rather than an explicit 'is a kind of external corrosion' phrase in this exact chunk.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on insulated external surfaces of piping and equipment
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: under thermal insulation and fireproofing systems
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Standard titles differentiate generic external corrosion control from corrosion under thermal insulation, suggesting a specialization.

evidence_excerpt:
RP 0169 Standard Recommended Practice: Control of External Corrosion on Underground or Submerged Metallic Piping Systems
RP 0198 The Control of Corrosion Under Thermal Insulation, and Fireproofing – A Systems Approach

relation_surface: These alloys are characterized by an austenitic structure.
rel_desc: Austenitic stainless steels are characterized by an austenitic metallurgical structure.
resolution_context: Direction chosen as alloy → microstructure because the text states the alloys are characterized by this structure.
justification: The text states that the austenitic stainless steels (these alloys) are characterized by an austenitic structure.
evidence_excerpt: These alloys are characterized by an austenitic structure.

relation_surface: contain a mixed austenitic-ferritic structure
rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel contains an austenitic component in its mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.
resolution_context: Direction duplex stainless steel → austenitic since the material contains this structure as part of its microstructure.
justification: Definition states duplex stainless steel is a family of stainless steels that contain a mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: The structure is explicitly described as mixed austenitic-ferritic.

evidence_excerpt: Duplex stainless steel – a family of stainless steels that contain a mixed austenitic-ferritic structure

relation_surface: contain a mixed austenitic-ferritic structure
rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel contains a ferritic component in its mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.

justification: The same phrase describing a mixed austenitic-ferritic structure implies ferritic is also a structural component.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: The structure is described as mixed austenitic-ferritic, so ferritic is part of the duplex microstructure.

evidence_excerpt: Duplex stainless steel – a family of stainless steels that contain a mixed austenitic-ferritic structure

relation_surface: The welds of 300 series stainless steels may also exhibit a duplex structure.
rel_desc: Welds of austenitic (300 series) stainless steels may exhibit a duplex stainless steel–type structure.
resolution_context: 300 series stainless steels correspond to austenitic stainless steels; relation models that their welds can show a duplex-type structure.
justification: Text explicitly notes that welds of 300 series stainless steels may exhibit a duplex structure, associating these alloys with duplex-type weld microstructures.
remark: Relation created to capture that the weld region of austenitic stainless steels can show duplex characteristics; structure vs alloy terminology slightly blurred.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Refers specifically to weld metal/heat-affected regions rather than base metal.

evidence_excerpt: The welds of 300 series stainless steels may also exhibit a duplex structure.

relation_surface: used in amine treating to remove H₂S and CO₂ from hydrocarbon streams
rel_desc: Methyldiethanolamine (MDEA) and monoethanolamine (MEA) are both used in amine treating processes to remove H₂S and CO₂ from hydrocarbon streams.
resolution_context: Direction chosen arbitrarily to express that both chemicals share essentially the same stated industrial application.
justification: The chunk separately defines MDEA and MEA with the same phrase: "used in amine treating to remove H₂S and CO₂ from hydrocarbon streams," implying they serve similar functions.
remark: Relation inferred from identical described use; not explicitly stated as a comparison but strongly implied.
evidence_excerpt:
Methyldiethanolamine (MDEA) – used in amine treating to remove H₂S and CO₂ from hydrocarbon streams.
Monoethanolamine (MEA) – used in amine treating to remove H₂S and CO₂ from hydrocarbon streams.
